Award.AwardTitle: Excessive Bridge Deflections: Inverse Analysis to Identify Multi-Decade Creep Properties of Concrete

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The resaerch objective of this project is to use actual data on excessive creep deflections to find a realistic multi-decade concrete creep law. The fatal collapse of KB Bridge in Palau, a segmental box-girder bridge of world record span, called attention to the preceding creep deflections, which attained 1.61m, nearly 5-times the design deflection. Forced unsealing of the technical data on this bridge allowed Northwestern University researchers to conclude that the standard design recommendations were obsolete. This motivated a broad search which has so far led to a collection of 64 large-span bridges deflecting excessively within 20 to 40 years, while supposed to serve >100 years. The main cause of this obsoleteness is that most laboratory creep data have durations <6 years. The bridge deflection data are combined in one aggregate database, and an inverse three-dimensional finite-element creep analysis of box-girder deflections is combined with the lab database to calibrate an improved material law for creep of concrete. Sophisticated statistical concepts and a genetic algorithm are used to predict the parameters of material creep law from the concrete composition characteristics and strength. The results will be proposed for standard design recommendations of engineering societies.

Although the societal costs of retrofits or closings of numerous excessive deflecting bridges are enormous, their data represent a gold mine for progress. The research will clarify how to avoid repetitions, which causes serviceability losses and cracking with corrosion. An improved creep model will also be important for design against differential shortening of columns in modern super-tall buildings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most advances in structural engineering come in response to failures and damages. Concrete creep and shrinkage are no different. For example, excessive creep deflections typically cause excessive cracking, which allows the ingress of corrosive agents and corrosion of reinforcement.

 One stimulus was provided by the fatal 1996 collapse of the KB Bridge in Palau with the span of 241 m, which was the world record for a segmentally erected prestressed box girder. The collapse, triggered by an unsuccessful retrofit, brought attention to an underlying problem, namely that this bridge suffered grossly excessive creep deflections, which reached 1.61 m (compared to design camber), and a prestress loss of about 50%. Both occurred within only 18 years, while it is desired that most large bridges be designed for a lifetime of at least 100 years.

Based on this fact, and thanks to NSF support, the PI proposed to RILEM, an old Paris-based international society issuing international recommendations on civil engineering materials and structures, to organize a committee no this problem. The proposal was approved and the PI founded RILEM Committee TC-MDC (Multi-Decade Creep), to help with collecting data needed for the work on the NSF grant. An exhaustive search by the PI and coworkers, in collaboration with this committee, led to a collection of multi-decade deflection data on 69 large-span prestressed bridges from around the world, most of which suffered excessive deflections resulting in bridge closing or costly retrofit. The analysis revealed that all the design codes and standard recommendations led to severe underestimation of multi-decade creep.

   To support the mathematical modeling, a large worldwide database of laboratory creep and shrinkage tests, more than doubling the size of the previous RILEM database, was assembled. It included over 4000 test series, and in contrast to previous databases, included data on modern concretes with various kinds of admixtures which lead to significant autogenous shrinkage, in addition to the drying shrinkage (some of these test were carried out at Northwestern University). However, in the database, 95% of all creep tests have a duration of less than 6-years and only a few exceed 12 years. This is insufficient for calibrating and validating multi-decade prediction models, and this was why the database of long-time bridge deflections became essential. Sophisticated inverse computer analysis, both mechanical and statistical, was conducted to extract the creep properties from the observed deflections of 69 bridges. 

   This new laboratory database, combined with the bridge database (both made publicly available) was essential to calibrate and verify a new theoretically derived model for creep and shrinkage of concrete, labelled model B4, to be used in structural analysis. This model was in 2015, after extensive scrutiny, approved by RILEM as its new International Recommendation. The model is theoretically supported by the solidification theory, by the theory of microprestress relaxation in the nano-structure of cement, by the activation energy concepts, by moisture diffusion theory and by the damage model for microcracking. The parameters of this model are expressed as functions of the concrete strength, mix composition, cement and aggregate types, and curing procedure, which were calibrated by the new combined laboratory and bridge database. Simultaneous optimization of the bridge and lab databases provided essential information for updating the asymptotic slope of creep curves in the semi-logarithmic scale. The database expansion made it also possible to include the autogenous shrinkage, which was not separately considered in previous models, and take into account further influences such as the mineralogical type of aggregate, and extend applicability to modern concretes. For th...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Most advances in structural engineering come in response to failures and damages. Concrete creep and shrinkage are no different. For example, excessive creep deflections typically cause excessive cracking, which allows the ingress of corrosive agents and corrosion of reinforcement. One stimulus was provided by the fatal 1996 collapse of the KB Bridge in Palau with the span of 241 m, which was the world record for a segmentally erected prestressed box girder. The collapse, triggered by an unsuccessful retrofit, brought attention to an underlying problem, namely that this bridge suffered grossly excessive creep deflections, which reached 1.61 m (compared to design camber), and a prestress loss of about 50%. Both occurred within only 18 years, while it is desired that most large bridges be designed for a lifetime of at least 100 years. Based on this fact, and thanks to NSF support, the PI proposed to RILEM, an old Paris-based international society issuing international recommendations on civil engineering materials and structures, to organize a committee no this problem. The proposal was approved and the PI founded RILEM Committee TC-MDC (Multi-Decade Creep), to help with collecting data needed for the work on the NSF grant. An exhaustive search by the PI and coworkers, in collaboration with this committee, led to a collection of multi-decade deflection data on 69 large-span prestressed bridges from around the world, most of which suffered excessive deflections resulting in bridge closing or costly retrofit. The analysis revealed that all the design codes and standard recommendations led to severe underestimation of multi-decade creep. To support the mathematical modeling, a large worldwide database of laboratory creep and shrinkage tests, more than doubling the size of the previous RILEM database, was assembled. It included over 4000 test series, and in contrast to previous databases, included data on modern concretes with various kinds of admixtures which lead to significant autogenous shrinkage, in addition to the drying shrinkage (some of these test were carried out at Northwestern University). However, in the database, 95% of all creep tests have a duration of less than 6-years and only a few exceed 12 years. This is insufficient for calibrating and validating multi-decade prediction models, and this was why the database of long-time bridge deflections became essential. Sophisticated inverse computer analysis, both mechanical and statistical, was conducted to extract the creep properties from the observed deflections of 69 bridges. This new laboratory database, combined with the bridge database (both made publicly available) was essential to calibrate and verify a new theoretically derived model for creep and shrinkage of concrete, labelled model B4, to be used in structural analysis. This model was in 2015, after extensive scrutiny, approved by RILEM as its new International Recommendation. The model is theoretically supported by the solidification theory, by the theory of microprestress relaxation in the nano-structure of cement, by the activation energy concepts, by moisture diffusion theory and by the damage model for microcracking. The parameters of this model are expressed as functions of the concrete strength, mix composition, cement and aggregate types, and curing procedure, which were calibrated by the new combined laboratory and bridge database. Simultaneous optimization of the bridge and lab databases provided essential information for updating the asymptotic slope of creep curves in the semi-logarithmic scale. The database expansion made it also possible to include the autogenous shrinkage, which was not separately considered in previous models, and take into account further influences such as the mineralogical type of aggregate, and extend applicability to modern concretes. For the calibration, various strategies that help to suppress statistical bias due to non-systematic sampling were used. Th...
